titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Henry Alexander Scammell Dearborn papers, 1802-1848
titlestmt.author: Processed by: Rubenstein Staff; EAD finding aid derived from MARC record using marc2ead_sectionA.xsl

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid derived from MARC record via marc2ead_sectionA.xsl, September 2018

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University

origination.label: Creator
origination.persname: Dearborn, H. A. S. (Henry Alexander Scammell), 1783-1851

did.abstract: Collection consists of assorted correspondence relating to national and state politics, nullification, and internal improvements, especially canals and railroads in the Boston area and in Pennsylvania. Includes discussion of a treaty with the Tuscarora Indians in N.C.; the 1832 presidential election; and the nullification crisis. Correspondents include Henry Dearborn (H.A.S. Dearborn's father), Joseph Gardner Swift, and Gerard Ralston.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

prefercite.p: Henry Alexander Scammell Dearborn Papers, 1802-1848, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.p: This finding aid was derived from a MARC record using a crosswalk defined in marc2ead_sectionA.xsl. The finding aid was generated as part of a larger project to digitize several thousand small collections housed in Section A, September 2018.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Collection consists of assorted correspondence relating to national and state politics, nullification, and internal improvements, especially canals and railroads in the Boston area and in Pennsylvania. Includes discussion of a treaty with the Tuscarora Indians in N.C.; the 1832 presidential election; and the nullification crisis. Correspondents include Henry Dearborn (H.A.S. Dearborn's father), Joseph Gardner Swift, and Gerard Ralston.

odd.p: Portions of this collection were originally part of the Don Preston Peters collection. Cataloged from card file; description dates from 1936-1960s.
